Knowledge Point: The basic constituent order in Mauwake clauses is quite rigid \textstyleAcronymallcaps{sov}, even if the verb morphology cross-references the syntactic roles to some extent. Although only a fraction of the clauses in the text corpus -- less than 10% -- have an overt subject and object \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} it is possible to establish the dominant order. About nine out of ten of those clauses that do have an overt subject and object \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} manifest \textstyleAcronymallcaps{sov} order.\footnote{SOV: 210 clauses, OSV: 22 clauses} They are also pragmatically neutral \REF{ex:5:x896}, whereas the other possible order, \textstyleAcronymallcaps{osv}, only occurs when the object is fronted as a theme \REF{ex:5:x897}.
Content 1: \gll Owow mua\textsubscript{S} kau kuisow\textsubscript{O} aaw-e-mik. | \gls village man cow one get-PA-1/3p | \glt  `The village men got one cow.'
Content 2: \gll Yena aamun\textsubscript{O} ariwa=ke\textsubscript{S} aaw-o-k. | \gls 1s.POSS 1s/p.younger.sibling arrow=CF get-PA-3s | \glt  `My younger brother was killed by an arrow.'

Knowledge Point: There are two object positions\footnote{The two objects are discussed further in the next sections \sectref{sec:5.2} and \sectref{sec:5.3}} and three X-positions for adverbial phrases. Depending on the grammatical model, the adverbial phrases may be called peripherals, obliques, satellites or adjuncts. I call them peripherals and reserve the term adjunct for the non-verb part of an adjunct plus verb construction. If a clause has only one object, it occupies the O\textsubscript{2} position immediately preceding the verb regardless of whether the semantic function is that of a patient, a recipient or a beneficiary. When there are two objects, their position is dictated mainly by their relative topicality. A [+human] argument tends to be more topical than a [\nobreakdash-human] one, so an object that is semantically a recipient \REF{ex:5:x928}, \REF{ex:5:x933}, or a beneficiary \REF{ex:5:x916}, typically occupies the first object position, and the other object, typically a [\nobreakdash-human] patient, fills the second object position.
Content 1: \gll Muuka\textsubscript{O1} sira\textsubscript{O2} iw-i-mik. | \gls son custom give.him-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt  `They teach the right behaviour to the son.'
Content 2: \gll Sarak=ke wi takira\textsubscript{O1} inglis\textsubscript{O2} wia\textsubscript{O1} ofakow-i-ya.{\upshape\footnotemark} | \gls Sarak=CF 3p.UNM child English 3p.ACC teach-Np-PR.3s | \glt  `Sarak teaches the children English.'
Content 3: \gll Ni auwa\textsubscript{O1} maa\textsubscript{O2} p-ikiw-om-aka. | \gls 2p.UNM 1s/p.father food BPX-go-BEN-BNFY2.IMP.2p | \glt  `Take food to/for father.'

Knowledge Point: If a [-human] patient object is more topical than a [+human] object, it can occupy the first object position. A more topical [+human] object in \REF{ex:5:x917} would have an unmarked third person plural pronoun before the [-human] object.\footnote{More examples of can be found in \sectref{sec:5.3.2}.}
Content 1: \gll Onak=ke aaya\textsubscript{O1} wia\textsubscript{O2} aaw-om-aya enim-or-om-ik-e-mik. | \gls 3s/p.mother sugarcane 3p.ACC get-BEN-BNFY2.2/3s eat-descend-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p | \glt  `Their mother got sugarcane for them and they went down eating it.'

Knowledge Point: If both the objects are [-human], the one that is more clearly the patient, i.e. more profoundly affected by the action, occupies the O\textsubscript{2} position \REF{ex:5:x927}. Usually the object in O\textsubscript{1} position has a more locative-type meaning \REF{ex:5:x934}.
Content 1: \gll Epira\textsubscript{O1} lolom\textsubscript{O2} if-e-mik. | \gls plate mud smear-PA-1/3p | \glt  `They smeared the plate with mud' or: `They smeared mud on the plate.'
Content 2: \gll Wut makena nain\textsubscript{O1} ona\textsubscript{O2} puuk-a-m. | \gls Derris.root.tree seed that1 hole cut-PA-1s | \glt  `I cut a hole in the seed of a derris root tree.'

Knowledge Point: The normal position of the peripherals is between the subject and the object \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}, if any \REF{ex:5:x895}, or between the first and second object \REF{ex:5:x913}.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll Wiipa nain\textsubscript{O1} \textbf{samapora} \textbf{iinan=pa}\textsubscript{AdvP} epia\textsubscript{O2} ururum-om-ap{\dots} | \gls daughter that floor top=LOC fire light-BEN-BNFY2.SS.SEQ | \glt  `They lighted a fire for the daughter on top of the floor, and ...'

Knowledge Point: A locative adverbial can also come between an object \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} and a verb. A deictic locative phrase \REF{ex:5:x914} or another short locative phrase \REF{ex:5:x931} is common in this position.
Content 1: \gll Emer en-ow(a) mua=ko emeria\textsubscript{O} \textbf{fan}\textsubscript{AdvP} aaw-o-k. | \gls sago eat-NMZ man=NF woman here get-PA-3s | \glt  `A Sepik man got a wife here.'
Content 2: \gll Yo maa unowa\textsubscript{O} \textbf{koora=pa}\textsubscript{AdvP} wu-a-m. | \gls 1s.UNM thing many house=LOC put-PA-1s | \glt  `I put (the) many things in the house.'

Knowledge Point: The position immediately before the verb is also the only possible place for a [+human] locative adverbial, manifested by a dative pronoun (\sectref{sec:3.5.5}). In both \REF{ex:5:x854} and \REF{ex:5:x855} there are two locative adverbials, a [-human] and a [+human] one. The [+human] locative adverbial refers to the people of the location. If it is left out, the other locative refers to the location but not the people.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll I amirk=iw Gawar\textsubscript{AdvP} \textbf{wiar}\textsubscript{AdvP} urup-e-mik. | \gls 1p.UNM day=INST Gawar 3.DAT ascend-PA-1/3p | \glt  `During the day we went to Gawar.'

Knowledge Point: If there are more adverbial phrases than one, a temporal phrase normally precedes any others \REF{ex:5:x915}. The relative order of the other adverbial phrases is syntactically quite free and depends on their relative topicality \REF{ex:5:x915}, \REF{ex:5:x918}.
Content 1: \gll I \textbf{amirika} \textbf{owowa} \textbf{ewur} me ekap-em-ik-e-mik. | \gls 1p.UNM day village quickly not come-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p | \glt  `In the daytime we didn't come quickly to the village.'
Content 2: \gll I \textbf{amirika} \textbf{owowa} \textbf{ewur} me ekap-em-ik-e-mik. | \gls 1p.UNM day village quickly not come-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p | \glt  `In the daytime we didn't come quickly to the village.'
Content 3: \gll Niena \textbf{ikoka} \textbf{oram} \textbf{neeke} ika-i-non. | \gls 2s/p.mother later for.nothing there.CF be-Np-FU.3s | \glt  `Your mother will later just be there (without you).'

Knowledge Point: Both transitive \REF{ex:5:x981} and intransitive clauses \REF{ex:5:x1057} are negated with the verbal negator \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{me} `not' placed immediately before the verb phrase.\footnote{For the placement of me as a constituent negator, see \sectref{sec:6.2.2}.}
Content 1: \gll I \textbf{me} wia amukar-e-mik. | \gls 1p.UNM not 3.ACC scold-PA-1/3p | \glt  `We didn't scold them.'
Content 2: \gll Nain yo \textbf{me} baurar-em-ik-e-m. | \gls but 1s.UNM not run.away-SS.SIM-be-PA-1s | \glt  `But I didn't keep running away.'

Knowledge Point: As was mentioned above, pragmatic factors influence the constituent order. A constituent that is fronted as a theme to the beginning of the clause is still part of the constituent structure of the clause \REF{ex:5:x930} (for theme, see \sectref{sec:9.1}).\footnote{In Amele the pre-verbal position is a focus position \citep[142]{Roberts1987}, but in Mauwake this does not seem to be the case. Focus is indicated by a heavier stress and sometimes by focus markers.}
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Oposia} \textbf{gelemuta}\textsubscript{O1} wiam erup fain wia\textsubscript{O2} wu-om-a-m. | \gls meat little 3p.REFL two this 3p.ACC put-BEN-BNFY2.PA-1s | \glt  `A bit of the meat I put (aside) for these two.'

Knowledge Point: A left-dislocated theme (\sectref{sec:9.1}) and an afterthought are outside the clause proper. A left-dislocated theme \REF{ex:5:x935} is separated from the clause by a short pause and a comma intonation, slightly rising pitch at the end of the utterance. An afterthought \REF{ex:5:x929}, right-dislocated, is also separated from the rest of the clause by a short pause.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Irak-owa fa}, opora unowa akena. | \gls fight-NMZ INTJ talk much very | \glt  `The war, now - there is much to talk about.'
Content 2: \gll Inasin opaimika eliwa me yia maak-e-mik, \textbf{wi} \textbf{Yaapan=ke}. | \gls spirit talk good not 1p.ACC tell-PA-1/3p 3p.UNM Japan=CF | \glt  `They didn't speak good Pidgin to us, the Japanese (didn't).'

Knowledge Point: The syntactic coding of the subject includes both the clausal constituent order and cross-referencing on the verb \REF{ex:5:x936}. In pragmatically neutral clauses the subject is the first of two argument noun phrases. It is also obligatorily marked on the person/number suffix of the verb. The same distinctions are made in the subject marking of the verb as in the personal pronouns: first, second or third person and singular or plural number.
Content 1: \gll Komori emeria wu-a-k. | \gls Komori woman put-PA-3s | \glt  `Komori buried his wife.'

Knowledge Point: The subject governs reflexivization. A noun phrase itself is marked as subject only when the subject \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} is a pronoun: then it has to be unmarked \REF{ex:5:x920} (\sectref{sec:3.5.2.1}) or in the genitive case (\sectref{sec:3.5.4}).
Content 1: \gll Tirinde uura \textbf{i} nainiw \textbf{yiam} fiirim-e-\textbf{mik}. | \gls Wednesday evening 1p.UNM again 1p.REFL gather-PA-1/3p | \glt  `On Wednesday evening we gathered again.'

Knowledge Point: The switch-reference system (\sectref{sec:8.2.3}) basically tracks the subject \REF{ex:5:x921}.\footnote{Roberts maintains that in Amele and most other Papuan languages the switch reference system tracks the thematic notion of topic across clauses (\citeyear[105]{Roberts1988b}, \citeyear{Roberts1997}). But his definition of topic (\citeyear[16]{Roberts1988b}) is such that in Mauwake it practically excludes all other clause constituents except the subject.}
Content 1: \gll {\dots}imen-\textbf{ap} maak-\textbf{iwkin} o miim-o-k. | \gls find-SS.SEQ tell-2/3p.DS 3s.UNM precede-PA-3s | \glt  `{\dots}when they found him and told him, he went ahead.'

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:5:x922}, the object/topic/theme of the first clause is the Australians; in the second clause they become the subject.
Content 1: \gll Wi Australia \textbf{Amerika=ke} wia asip-\textbf{iwkin} irak-owa nomak-e-mik. | \gls 3p.UNM Australia America=CF 3p.ACC help-2/3p.DS fight-NMZ win-PA-1/3p | \glt  `Australians were helped by Americans and won the war.'

Knowledge Point: Although the prototypical subject is a [+human] agent, also an instrument that is unable to initiate an action can become a metaphorical agent, thus the subject \citep[106]{Givon1984}. This is very common in expressions describing cases where one involuntarily hurts oneself with some instrument \REF{ex:5:x958}. (In the following example, there is also possessor raising (\sectref{sec:5.3.2.3}) resulting in two objects.)
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Fura=ke}\textsubscript{S} merena\textsubscript{O1} efa\textsubscript{O2} puuk-a-k. | \gls knife=CF leg 1s.ACC cut-PA-3s | \glt  `I cut my leg / myself in the leg.' (Lit: `A knife cut my leg.')

Knowledge Point: The \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{object}} as a syntactic role is not coded on the verb word except in the few object cross-referencing verbs (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.2.4}). A [+human] object must be referenced by an accusative pronoun (\sectref{sec:3.5.3}) preceding the verb in the verb phrase (\sectref{sec:4.5}), even if the object is also expressed by a full noun phrase earlier in the clause \REF{ex:5:x923}. The position of the object \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} in the argument structure of the clause is between the subject and the verb \REF{ex:5:x924}, but this syntactic definition is not very useful, as subject and object do not co-occur very often, and sometimes when they do, the object is fronted to the clause-initial theme position \REF{ex:5:x925}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Emeria} naap \textbf{wia} aruf-i-nen na-ep on-a-k. | \gls woman thus 3p.ACC hit-Np-FU.1s say-SS.SEQ do-PA-3s | \glt  `He tried to hit women that way.'
Content 2: \gll Amia mua=ke \textbf{wiam} \textbf{erup} \textbf{nain} \textbf{wia} nokar-e-k. | \gls bow man=CF 3p.REFL two that1 3p.ACC ask-PA-3s | \glt  `The policeman asked those two.'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Mua} \textbf{emeria} \textbf{muuka} \textbf{wiipa} eka=ke \textbf{wia} mu-o-k. | \gls man woman son daughter river=CF 3p.ACC swallow-PA-3s | \glt  `A man and his wife and children were drowned by the river.'

Knowledge Point: There is not enough basis in Mauwake for positing a separate syntactic category \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{indirect object}}. In many languages the most typical verb requiring an indirect object for the semantic role of recipient is `give'. But in Mauwake the verbs `give' and `feed/give to eat' are among the few object cross-referencing verbs (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.2.4}), which change their stem according to the patient or recipient object. The verb `send', another cross-linguistically typical verb taking an indirect object, in Mauwake requires the benefactive suffix on the verb (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.3.2}), rather than a marking on the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}. In \REF{ex:5:x932} the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{maak}- `tell' has two objects, the patient object \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{moma} `taro' and the recipient object \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{yia} `us', which is marked by an accusative pronoun in the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{vp} in the same way as a [+human] undergoer/patient.
Content 1: \gll Wi \textbf{moma}\textsubscript{O} \textbf{yia}\textsubscript{O} maak-i-mik. | \gls 3p.UNM taro 1p.ACC tell-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt  `They are telling us (to get them) taro.'

Knowledge Point: It could be argued that a locative adverbial is an argument rather than a peripheral clause constituent with the directional verbs\footnote{For Usan, where motion verbs have either the goal or locative as a nuclear argument, see \citet[130]{Reesink1987}.} (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.4.5}) and with the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}- `be/live (somewhere)' (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.4.1}), as these verbs so often co-occur with a locative. But these verbs also occur without a locative so often that it would be both unnatural to interpret all of those instances as elliptical constructions and sometimes difficult to posit the ``deleted'' locative \REF{ex:5:x1456}, \REF{ex:5:x1457}.
Content 1: \gll Maak-e-mik, ``No ikiw-e, irak-owa maneka fan-e-k a.'' | \gls tell-PA-1/3p 2s.UNM go-IMP.2s fight-NMZ big here-PA-3s INTJ | \glt  `They told him, ``Go, the war is here.'' '
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: The verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}- `be' seldom occurs alone \REF{ex:5:x1458}. This is probably due to its very neutral semantic character. When it denotes being or living somewhere, it is accompanied by a locative adverbial phrase \REF{ex:5:x1459}. Another very common adverbial phrase accompanying the verb is a manner phrase, especially the adverb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naap} `thus' \REF{ex:5:x1460}. Rather than positing separate clause types with adverbials as arguments it seems reasonable to subsume clauses like these under intransitive clauses.
Content 1: \gll Ika-i-nen. | \gls be-Np-FU.1s | \glt  `I will just be like this.'
Content 2: \gll Siiwa erepam naap \textbf{nan} \textbf{ik-ok} napuma sariar-e-k. | \gls moon four thus there be-SS sickness heal-PA-3s | \glt  `He was there about four months and his sickness was healed.'
Content 3: \gll Komor(a) muuka nain memel-am-ik-emkun \textbf{naap} \textbf{ik}\textbf{-}\textbf{ok} iir oko uura baurar-e-k. | \gls cuscus son that1 tame-SS.SIM-be-1s/p.DS thus be-SS time other night escape-PA-3s | \glt  `I was taming the cuscus and it was like that and then one night it escaped.'

Knowledge Point: Monotransitive clauses have a transitive verb and one object, which is prototypically a patient \REF{ex:5:x937}, \REF{ex:5:x939}.

Knowledge Point: If there is only one \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} argument in a transitive clause, it is usually the object rather than subject \REF{ex:5:x941}, unless marked with the contrastive focus marker -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ke} \REF{ex:5:x938}.

If it were the object, it would require the third person plural accusative pronoun \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{wia} in the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}.

Knowledge Point: Clauses with an impersonal experience verb (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.4.7}) as the predicate are also transitive. The subject is inanimate, usually a body part where the pain is felt, and the human experiencer is the object \REF{ex:5:x1012}, \REF{ex:5:x1015}. Knowledge Point: A number of ditransitive clauses \REF{ex:5:x928}--\REF{ex:5:x917} were already listed under \sectref{sec:5.1}. They belong to the three different groups below.

Knowledge Point: The (recipient) object is marked in the verb root of the object cross-referencing verbs denoting giving and feeding (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.2.4}), but it may appear as a separate \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} as well \REF{ex:5:x950}:
Content 1: \gll Mua yiar ekap-e-mik nain\textsubscript{O} pura kui-kuisow\textsubscript{O} wi-e-mik. | \gls man 1p.DAT come-PA-1/3p that bunch RDP-one give.them-PA-1/3p | \glt  `We gave a bunch each to the men who came to us.'

Knowledge Point: The section on utterance verbs (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.4.6}) describes in some detail how these verbs behave in clauses. \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Maak}- `tell' requires the addressee/recipient to be a [+human] obligatory object, and as a second object it often has a \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} denoting the speech itself \REF{ex:5:x1839} or the contents of that speech \REF{ex:5:x955}.

Knowledge Point: There are a few verbs that are ordinary transitive verbs but which can take semantically different objects. It is also possible to have one of each kind in the same clause. The verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{if}- `paint, spread' can have a patient or goal object; the sentence in example \REF{ex:5:x944} includes both. Another such verb is \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{mik}\nobreakdash- `spear, hit' \REF{ex:5:x953}.

Knowledge Point: When the transitivity is increased by one of the valence-increasing strategies (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.3}), a recipient or beneficiary \REF{ex:5:x947}, \REF{ex:5:x1840} becomes a second object. The linear order of the two objects depends on their relative topicality.

Content 2: \gll Ne mua nain\textsubscript{O} waaya\textsubscript{O} mik-om-a-mik. | \gls ADD man that1 pig spear-BEN-BNFY2.PA-1/3p | \glt  `And they speared that man a pig.'

Knowledge Point: There are also cases with two patient-type objects, either one of which could be the single patient of the same verb. One of these objects has resulted from possessor raising: the possessor of the initial object \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}, which has to be a semantic patient, has been ``raised'' to become a second object (\citealt[258]{VanValinEtAl1997}; \citealt[194--196]{Payne1997}). Especially when something is done to a body part \REF{ex:5:x951} or name \REF{ex:5:x952}, or something closely identified with a person \REF{ex:5:x957}--\REF{ex:5:x949}, both the person and the other noun occur as objects.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Merena}\textsubscript{O} \textbf{efa}\textsubscript{O} keraw-a-k. | \gls leg 1s.ACC bite-PA-3s | \glt  `It bit me in the leg.' Or: `It bit my leg.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{No} \textbf{unuma}\textsubscript{O} \textbf{nefa}\textsubscript{O} faker-i-kuan. | \gls 2s.UNM name 2s.ACC raise-Np-FU.3p | \glt  `They will praise (lit: raise) your name.'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Opaimika}\textsubscript{O} \textbf{efa}\textsubscript{O} fien-a-man. | \gls talk 1s.ACC push.aside-PA-2p | \glt  `You disregarded/disobeyed my talk.'
Content 4: \gll Mua papako=ke \textbf{irak-owa}\textsubscript{O} \textbf{wia}\textsubscript{O} puuk-a-mik. | \gls man some=CF fight-NMZ 3p.ACC cut-PA-1/3p | \glt  `Some men\textsubscript{i} stopped their\textsubscript{j} fight.'

Knowledge Point: Even three objects are allowed, but this is rare \REF{ex:5:x953}: the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{mik}- `spear, hit' itself allows two different objects, and the third one is added via possessor raising. The objects have to be in this order. Note that in the English translation, only one direct object is allowed, and the other two phrases have to be either possessive or oblique.
Content 1: \gll [\textbf{Keema-muuna}, \textbf{umakuna}]\textsubscript{O} \textbf{meta}\textsubscript{O} \textbf{yia}\textsubscript{O} \textbf{mik-i-mik}. | \gls knee-joint neck ritual.paste 1p.ACC hit-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt  `They stick the \textstyleForeignWords{meta} paste on our knees and necks' or: `They mark our knees and necks with the \textstyleForeignWords{meta} paste.'

Knowledge Point: As the preferred clause structure in Mauwake is short and because it is harder to process a verb with many arguments, a common strategy is to divide the arguments between more than one clause, so that each clause has only one or two arguments \REF{ex:5:x967}.
Content 1: \gll I dabuela aaw-ep Yaapan wi-em-ik-e-mik. | \gls 1p.UNM pawpaw take-SS.SEQ Japan give.them-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p | \glt  `We took pawpaws and gave them to the Japanese' or: `We gave pawpaws to the Japanese.'

Knowledge Point: Even if having more than one \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} in non-subject argument or peripheral positions in the same clause is not preferred, it is still reasonably common. But having more than one pronoun as arguments or peripherals is unusual. In the rare case that that does happen, the accusative pronoun occupies the position closest to the verb \REF{ex:5:x1574}, \REF{ex:5:x1577}, next the dative pronoun \REF{ex:5:x1575}, then the others. The first two of the following three examples have been elicited.
Content 1: \gll Mua nain teeria muutiw \textbf{wame} \textbf{wia} ofakow-a-k. | \gls man that group only 3s.REFL 3p.ACC show-PA-3s | \glt  `He only showed himself to that man's group.'
Content 2: \gll O \textbf{wiar} \textbf{nefa} sesek-i-yem. | \gls 3s.UNM 3.DAT 2s.ACC send-Np-PR.1s | \glt  `I am sending you to him.'
Content 3: \gll Emeria ikoka Yaapan \textbf{wiena} \textbf{niar} aaw-i-kuan | \gls woman later Japan 3p.GEN 2p.DAT take-Np-FU.3p | \glt  `Later the Japanese will take your wives as their own.'

Knowledge Point: The following clauses \REF{ex:5:x961}--\REF{ex:5:x968} are typical intransitive clauses:
Content 1: \gll Epa wiim-eya mua karer-omak-e-mik. | \gls place dawn-2/3s.DS man gather-DISTR/PL-PA-1/3p | \glt  `When it got light a lot of people gathered.'
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Many climate expressions \REF{ex:5:x1020}--\REF{ex:5:x1021} are normal intransitive clauses.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Epa} \textbf{kokom-ar-eya} in-e-mik. | \gls place dark-INCH-2/3s.DS sleep-PA-1/3p | \glt  `It became dark and we slept.'

Knowledge Point: The resultative verbs (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.4.4}) require a nominal argument, i.e., a noun \REF{ex:5:x966} or an adjective \REF{ex:5:x963}, expressing the result of change:
Content 1: \gll Arim-emi \textbf{emeria} \textbf{ar-e-k}. | \gls grow-SS.SIM woman become-PA-3s | \glt  `She grew and became a woman.'
Content 2: \gll Mua eneka, woosa \textbf{kia} \textbf{kir-em-ik-ua}. | \gls man tooth head white turn-SS.SIM-be-PA.3s | \glt  `The people's teeth and skulls were turning white.'

Knowledge Point: A few intransitive verbs can occur with a syntactic object or object-like element whose semantic role is not a patient. These differ from true patient objects in that the range of possible ``objects'' for those verbs is very restricted, they cannot be substituted with an accusative pronoun, and the verb cannot occur with the dummy object \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{maa} `thing'. The first type can be called a ``content object'' \REF{ex:5:x308} \citep[179]{HakulinenEtAl1979}%Karlsson
Content 1: \gll Wis pun wiisa uf-e-mik. | \gls 3p.FC too wiisa dance-PA-1/3p | \glt  `They, too, danced ``wiisa''.'

Knowledge Point: The second type is an object-like adverbial, as it functions in the same way as an adverbial phrase \REF{ex:5:x307}.
Content 1: \gll Era maala soomar-e-mik\textbf{\textmd{.}} | \gls way long walk-PA-1/3p | \glt  `We walked a long way.'

Knowledge Point: Existential clauses are not very common in Mauwake. \citet[741]{Givon1990} names these clauses as one of the main devices for introducing a new topic into a discourse, but in Mauwake they are not used very much in that function (\sectref{sec:9.2.1}). Existential clauses use the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}- `be' as their predicate, and they often contain a locative phrase \REF{ex:5:x970}, but it is not necessary \REF{ex:5:x971}, \REF{ex:5:x1067}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Aaya=ko} \textbf{feeke} \textbf{ik-eya} nefa aaw-ep enim-i-yen. | \gls sugarcane=NF here.CF be-2/3s.DS 2s.ACC take-SS.SEQ eat-Np-FU.1p | \glt  `If there is (any) sugarcane here, we'll take and eat you (the sugarcane).'
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gll Waaya ika-i-non-(na) waaya uup-i-nan. | \gls pig be-Np-FU.3s-(TP) pig cook-Np-FU.2s | \glt  `If there is a pig, you will cook a pig.'

Knowledge Point: Both the past \REF{ex:5:x1068} and future tense forms \REF{ex:5:x1067} can be used; the past tense may be used for both present and past meaning.
Content 1: \gll Kuisow owowa=pa=ko me ik-ua. | \gls one village=LOC=NF not be-PA.3s | \glt  `There was/is not even one in the village.'
Content 2: \gll Waaya ika-i-non-(na) waaya uup-i-nan. | \gls pig be-Np-FU.3s-(TP) pig cook-Np-FU.2s | \glt  `If there is a pig, you will cook a pig.'

Knowledge Point: A special type of existential clause has one of the two location verbs (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.4.3}) as the predicate. These verbs are only used in the past tense, even with the present tense meaning \REF{ex:5:x1154}, \REF{ex:5:x1155}.
Content 1: \gll Nomokowa unowa \textbf{fan-e-mik}, aakisa wia uruf-i-n. | \gls 2s/p.brother many here-PA-1/3p now 3p.ACC see-Np-PR.2s | \glt  `Many of your brothers are here, now you see them.'
Content 2: \gll No niawi akena \textbf{nan-e-k}, no fain me nena niawi akena=ke. | \gls 2s.UNM 2s/p.father real there-PA-3s 2s.UNM this not 2s.GEN 2s/p.father real=CF | \glt  `Your real father is there, this isn't your real father.'

Knowledge Point: Possessive clauses, or so-called `have' clauses, are formed with a dative pronoun and the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}- `be' \REF{ex:5:x595}. This is a grammaticalization from [+human] locative constructions with the semantic function of goal or locative \citep[50--61]{Heine1997}, as was already mentioned in \sectref{sec:3.5.5}.
Content 1: \gll Aaya \textbf{efar} \textbf{ikua}, ifera wia. | \gls sugar 1s.DAT be-PA.3s salt no | \glt  `I have sugar, but no(t) salt.'

Knowledge Point: The possessee is the patient-of-state subject, which is shown by the fact that it may take the contrastive focus clitic -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ke} \REF{ex:5:x1065} and it determines the person inflection on the verb as well \REF{ex:5:x1323}. The possessor is a \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{habitive adverbial}}, like a corresponding construction in Finnish is called \citep[209]{HakulinenEtAl1979}%Karlsson
Content 1: \gll Apu maa epira marok maneka=ke \textbf{wiar} \textbf{ik-ua}. | \gls Apu food plate prawn big=CF 3.DAT be-PA.3s | \glt  `Apu has/had big prawns on his food plate.' (Lit: `Apu's food plate\textsubscript{Theme} he has/had big prawns.')
Content 2: \gll Woos(a) mua \textbf{yiar} \textbf{ik-e-mik}, wis=ke eliw nia kaken-i-kuan. | \gls head man 1p.DAT be-PA-1/3p 3p.FC=CF well 2p.ACC straight-Np-FU.3p | \glt  `We have leaders, they can straighten you out.'

Knowledge Point: Because the possessee is typically inanimate and often indefinite whereas the possessor is human and definite, this causes a violation to the universal discourse-pragmatic principle, according to which animate/human and definite participants tend to precede inanimate and indefinite participants \citep[135]{Heine1997}. In order to follow the principle, Mauwake often makes the possessor a theme by moving the possessor noun phrase to sentence-initial position. Only the dative pronoun keeps its position immediately preceding the verb \REF{ex:5:x972}. If there is no other possessor \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}, an unmarked pronoun is used as a theme \REF{ex:5:x973}. In these two sentences, moving part of the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} to the theme position causes the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} to be non-contiguous. In the example \REF{ex:5:x595} the possessee subject \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{aaya} `sugar' is also the theme, and in \REF{ex:5:x1323} the possessee is animate/human, so in those clauses there is less pressure to make the possessor into the theme.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Mua} \textbf{oko}\textsubscript{Theme} ona koor miira=pa nan waaya unowa \textbf{wiar} \textbf{ik-ua}. | \gls man other 3s.GEN house face=LOC there pig many 3.DAT be-PA.3s | \glt  `Another man has many pigs there in front of his house.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{I}\textsubscript{Theme} sira naap me \textbf{yiar} \textbf{ik-ua}. | \gls 1p.UNM custom thus not 1p.DAT be-PA.3s | \glt  `We do not have a custom like that.'
Content 3: \gll Aaya \textbf{efar} \textbf{ikua}, ifera wia. | \gls sugar 1s.DAT be-PA.3s salt no | \glt  `I have sugar, but no(t) salt.'
Content 4: \gll Woos(a) mua \textbf{yiar} \textbf{ik-e-mik}, wis=ke eliw nia kaken-i-kuan. | \gls head man 1p.DAT be-PA-1/3p 3p.FC=CF well 2p.ACC straight-Np-FU.3p | \glt  `We have leaders, they can straighten you out.'

Knowledge Point: Clauses like the example \REF{ex:5:x1321}, where the possessed noun is [+human] and [+plural], triggering the plural form of the verb, are quite rare, and it seems that the singular verb form is also becoming possible in these cases:
Content 1: \gll Mua nain pun muuka wiipa \textbf{wiar} \textbf{ik-ua}. | \gls man that1 also son daughter 3.DAT ik-PA.3s | \glt  `That man also has children/son(s) and daughter(s).'

Knowledge Point: When the present tense form is used, it indicates a more transitory possession \REF{ex:5:x1201}:
Content 1: \gll Wis pun maa eliwa=ko wiar \textbf{ika-i-ya=na} iw-i-mik. | \gls 3p.UNM too thing good=NF 3.DAT be-Np-PR.3s=TP give.him-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt  `They too, if they (happen to) have good things, give to him.'

Knowledge Point: A possessive clause may be elliptical, with the verb deleted, in cases where the possessed \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} has at least one post-modifier, which most commonly is a quantifier \REF{ex:5:x1322}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: When the possessor is not human, the possessive clause is made with the existential verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}- `be' plus a comitative construction rather than the dative pronoun, and the possessor always precedes the possessee \REF{ex:5:x1807}, \REF{ex:5:x1810}. These are cross-linguistically typical features for the grammaticalization strategy that uses a comitative phrase for a possessive predication \citep[53--57]{Heine1997}. As was noted in \sectref{sec:3.5.4}, in this case the third person singular genitive pronoun \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ona} is used for a non-human possessor.
Content 1: \gll Parina ona wakesim-owa \textbf{onaiya} ika-i-ya. | \gls lamp 3s.GEN cover-NMZ with be-Np-PR.3s | \glt  `The lamp has a cover.'
Content 2: \gll Miiwa ona mua \textbf{onaiya} ik-ua. | \gls land 3s.GEN man with be-PA.3s | \glt  `The land has its men.' (Each piece of ground ``has'' men whose responsibility it is to see how the land is allocated for gardens.)

Knowledge Point: The predicate of a verbless clause belongs to some other phrase class than the verbs. The two subtypes below, equative \REF{ex:5:x1036} and descriptive clauses \REF{ex:5:x1037}, are very similar syntactically; their differences are mainly in the semantics of the predicates. Their negation strategies are also slightly different from each other.
Content 1: \gll Mua nain yena kae panewowa=ke. | \gls man that1 1s.GEN 1s/p.grandfather old=CF | \glt  `That man is my old grandfather.'
Content 2: \gll Waaya nain me maneka, muuka kia gelemuta. | \gls pig that1 not big son white small | \glt  `The pig wasn't big, it was a small white piglet.'

Knowledge Point: In certain cases the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}- `be' is required as a copula. This happens mainly in the future \REF{ex:5:x986} or sometimes in the past tense, or when the clause requires a medial form to indicate that it is a medial clause \REF{ex:5:x987}.
Content 1: \gll Ikoka mua eliwa ne mua oona ika-i-nan. | \gls later man good and man bone be-Np-FU.2p | \glt  `Later you will be a good and strong man.'
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: In an equative clause the subject and the non-verbal predicate have the same reference, so their order can be reversed with the basic meaning staying the same \REF{ex:5:x975}, \REF{ex:5:x976}.
Content 1: \gll Dogimaw yiena owow saria=ke. | \gls Dogimaw 1p.GEN village headman=CF | \glt  `Dogimaw is our village headman.'
Content 2: \gll Yiena owow saria Dogimaw(=ke). | \gls Our village headman Dogimaw(=CF) | \glt  `Our village headman is Dogimaw.'

Knowledge Point: An equative clause is only negated with the verbal negator \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{me} \REF{ex:5:x1752}:
Content 1: \gll Dogimaw me yiena owow saria=ke. | \gls Dogimaw not 1p.GEN village headman=CF | \glt  `Dogimaw is not our village headman.'

Knowledge Point: In classifying clauses,\footnote{\citet[233]{Dryer2007b} calls them ``clauses with a true nominal predicate''.} the reference of the subject is not identical with the reference of the predicate \REF{ex:5:x977}, \REF{ex:5:x978}.
Content 1: \gll Yo inasin mua=ke. | \gls 1s.UNM spirit man=CF | \glt  `I am a spirit man.'
Content 2: \gll Oo Kululu takira=ke, o me amis-ar-e-k. | \gls oh Kululu young.person=CF 3s.UNM not knowledge-INCH-PA-3s | \glt  `Oh, Kululu is a youth (compared to us), he doesn't know.'

Knowledge Point: The classifying clauses are negated with the verbal negator \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{me} \REF{ex:5:x980} or with a clause-final negator \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{weetak/wia} \REF{ex:5:x984}.\footnote{\citet[272]{Berghall2006} also gives marew `no(ne)' as a possible negator for equative clauses, but actually the equative clauses do not use it, only the descriptive clauses.}
Content 1: \gll Nain me inasin mua=ke, iperuma=ke. | \gls that1 not spirit man=CF eel=CF | \glt  `That is not a spirit man, it is an eel.'
Content 2: \gll O somek mua weetak/wia. | \gls he song man no | \glt  `He is not a teacher (lit: song man).'

Knowledge Point: A descriptive clause is very much like an equative clause, but the predicate is an adjective phrase \REF{ex:5:x974}, a noun phrase with an adjective \REF{ex:5:x988}, or less frequently a numeral \REF{ex:5:x979} or an adverbial phrase \REF{ex:5:x985}. On the time-stability scale these predicates are in between verbal and nominal predicates.
Content 1: \gll Irak-owa nain kekanowa akena. | \gls fight-NMZ that1 strong very | \glt  `The fighting was very fierce.'
Content 2: \gll Yo (mua) maala marew. | \gls 1s.UNM (man) long no(ne) | \glt  `I am not (a) tall (man).'
Content 3: \gll Yiena miiwa kuisow. | \gls 1p.GEN land one | \glt  `Our land is one.'
Content 4: \gll Nain pun sira naap=iw, mua me kerer-e-mik. | \gls that1 too custom thus=INST man not appear-PA-1/3p | \glt  `That, too, was like that: people didn't arrive.'

Knowledge Point: A descriptive clause can use any of the negation strategies available in Mauwake \REF{ex:5:x990}--\REF{ex:5:x989} (\sectref{sec:3.10}, \ref{sec:6.2}).
Content 1: \gll Biiris me eliwa, damo-damola=ko. | \gls bridge not good RDP-bad=NF | \glt  `The bridges were not good, they were bad.'
Content 2: \gll Awuliak nain eliwa weetak/wia. | \gls sweet.potato that1 good no | \glt  `That sweet potato is not good.'

Knowledge Point: The existential (\sectref{sec:5.5.1}) and possessive clauses (\sectref{sec:5.5.2}) are different from the other verbal clauses with regard to negation. Besides the standard verbal negation they can use all the other negators as well \REF{ex:5:x982} \REF{ex:5:x983} (\sectref{sec:6.2.1}). The verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}- `be' is retained only with the verbal negator \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{me}. With all the other negators the negator itself replaces the verb, and the clause becomes a verbless clause:
Content 1: \gll Iiriw miiwa muuta nain irak-owa \textbf{marew}. | \gls earlier land for that1 fight-NMZ no(ne) | \glt  `Earlier there was no fighting for land.'
Content 2: \gll I urupa \textbf{weetak}, i soomia \textbf{wia}, i epira \textbf{marew}. | \gls 1p.UNM cup no 1p.UNM spoon no 1p.UNM plate no(ne) | \glt  `We had no cups, no spoons, no plates.'

Knowledge Point: Neutralization of tense or aspect distinctions, as well as the loss of other than just one argument are common features associated with nominalization \citep[737--738]{HopperEtAl1984}. In Mauwake the nominalized verb forms may keep all of the derivational suffixes but not the inflectional ones, which include tense and person/number marking \REF{ex:5:x1226}.
Content 1: \gll Aakisa=ko me kerer-em-ika-i-ya, wia bala op-aw-ap wia \textbf{wiim-om-owa} nain.{\upshape\footnotemark} | \gls now=NF not appear-SS.SIM-be-Np-PR.3s 3p.ACC decoration hold-CAUS-SS.SEQ 3p.ACC escort-BEN-NMZ that1 | \glt  `Now it doesn't take place (any more), decorating them and escorting them for them (i.e. escorting girls to their prospective husbands).'

Knowledge Point: Verbal groups showing aspect may be nominalized as well, so the aspectual distinction is retained \REF{ex:5:x1841}:
Content 1: \gll Mua papako maa \textbf{ik-em-ik-owa} nain kawus wiar uruf-i-kuan. | \gls man some food roast-SS.SIM-be-NMZ that1 smoke 3.DAT see-Np-FU.3p | \glt  `They will see the smoke from some men's roasting of food.'

Knowledge Point: The nominalized verb in itself is neutral in regard to modality, even if it often gets deontic interpretation. But it can be, and frequently is, used in cases where modality is intentionally left unspecified. In \REF{ex:5:x1257} the reason for not coming may be that one is not allowed, or able, or willing, to come.
Content 1: \gll Yo \textbf{ekap-owa} wia. | \gls 1s.UNM come-NMZ no | \glt  `I won't come.'

Knowledge Point: But note \REF{ex:5:x1238} where the contrastive focus marker added to the nominalized verb forces a deontic interpretation. See also \sectref{sec:6.1.2}.
Content 1: \gll I uuw-owa yi-iwkin \textbf{baliwep} \textbf{uuw-owa=ke} ik-ua. | \gls 1p.UNM work-NMZ give.us-2/3p.DS well work-NMZ=CF be-PA.3s | \glt  `When they give us work, working well is our duty.'

Knowledge Point: The nominalized verb can keep all the arguments and peripherals that a corresponding finite verb would have. This sometimes results in very long noun phrases. In \REF{ex:5:x1234} there is lexical nominalization of the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kookal}- `like' as well, besides the clausal nominalization.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Manin(a)} \textbf{maneka}, \textbf{ekina}, \textbf{naisow} \textbf{nena} \textbf{kookal-owa}\textbf{=pa} \textbf{perek-owa} weetak. | \gls garden big ekina 2s.ISOL 2s.GEN like-NMZ=LOC pull.out-NMZ no | \glt  `You are not allowed to harvest the big garden, called ekina, at your own liking.'

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:5:x1235} and \REF{ex:5:x1236} only the nominalized verb is within the scope of the negation. The nominalized clauses are in brackets.
Content 1: \gll Maa eneka \textbf{me} \textbf{en-owa} maa marew. | \gls thing tooth not eat-NMZ thing none | \glt  `Not eating meat is all right / is not an issue.'
Content 2: \gll Wi mua naap \textbf{me} \textbf{on-owa} nain=ko ik-e-mik=i? | \gls 3p.UNM man thus not do-NMZ that1=NF be-PA-1/3p=QM | \glt  `Are there people who wouldn't do / keep doing like that?'

Knowledge Point: Any of the four negators (\sectref{sec:6.2.1}) may be used to negate the nominalized clause \REF{ex:5:x1257}--\REF{ex:5:x1236}.
Content 1: \gll Yo \textbf{ekap-owa} wia. | \gls 1s.UNM come-NMZ no | \glt  `I won't come.'
Content 2: \gll Wi mua naap \textbf{me} \textbf{on-owa} nain=ko ik-e-mik=i? | \gls 3p.UNM man thus not do-NMZ that1=NF be-PA-1/3p=QM | \glt  `Are there people who wouldn't do / keep doing like that?'

Knowledge Point: . Mauwake keeps the adverbial \REF{ex:5:x1237}.
Content 1: \gll Wiena teeria \textbf{baliwep} \textbf{wia} \textbf{kakalt-owa} sira nain wia maak-e-k. | \gls 3p.GEN family well 3p.ACC look.after-NMZ custom that1 3p.ACC tell-PA-3s | \glt  `He talked to them about the custom of looking after their families well.'

Knowledge Point: . This is perhaps clearest with the subject, which in many languages gets possessive/genitive marking in a nominalized clause. In Mauwake this criterion is not very helpful. The pronominal subject of this first type of nominalized clause, if present, is often genitive \REF{ex:5:x1228}, but may be nominative as well. But also the subject of a finite clause can be nominative or genitive in form, depending on whether it is neutral or emphatic; and if the subject of a nominalized clause is also the theme, it is nominative rather than genitive \REF{ex:5:x1257}. A pronominal object in a nominalized clause is in the accusative \REF{ex:5:x1237}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Yiena} \textbf{owow} \textbf{maneka} \textbf{ikiw-owa} \textbf{nain} ma-i-yem. | \gls 1p.GEN village big go-NMZ that1 say-Np-PR.1s | \glt  `I am talking about our going to town.'
Content 2: \gll Yo \textbf{ekap-owa} wia. | \gls 1s.UNM come-NMZ no | \glt  `I won't come.'
Content 3: \gll Wiena teeria \textbf{baliwep} \textbf{wia} \textbf{kakalt-owa} sira nain wia maak-e-k. | \gls 3p.GEN family well 3p.ACC look.after-NMZ custom that1 3p.ACC tell-PA-3s | \glt  `He talked to them about the custom of looking after their families well.'

Knowledge Point: The nominalized verb may take an adjective as a modifier \REF{ex:5:x1240}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Kema} \textbf{suuw-owa} \textbf{eliwa} aaw-ep kekan-e-k. | \gls liver push-NMZ good get-SS.SEQ get.strong-PA-3s | \glt  `He got good thinking and became strong.'

Knowledge Point: Another structural indicator of the nominal status of a nominalized clause is the focus marking, which can be attached to the verb \REF{ex:5:x1238}.
Content 1: \gll I uuw-owa yi-iwkin \textbf{baliwep} \textbf{uuw-owa=ke} ik-ua. | \gls 1p.UNM work-NMZ give.us-2/3p.DS well work-NMZ=CF be-PA.3s | \glt  `When they give us work, working well is our duty.'

Knowledge Point: Nominalized clauses, like other noun phrases, use the far deictic \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nain} `that' as a determiner \REF{ex:5:x1842}, \REF{ex:5:x1843}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ona} \textbf{epa} \textbf{maneka} \textbf{or-owa} \textbf{nain} fofa=pa ... unow-iya taan-e-mik. | \gls 3s.GEN place big descend-NMZ that1 day=LOC ... many=COM fill-PA-1/3p | \glt  `On the day of his coming down to the big place {\dots} all of them filled (the place).'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Niena} \textbf{waaya} \textbf{mik-owa} \textbf{nain} on-ami kuep-i-man, niena maa=ke, niena wiowa=ke. | \gls 2p.GEN pig spear-NMZ that1 do-SS.SIM break-Np-PR.2p 2p.GEN thing=CF 2p.GEN spear=CF | \glt  `If you break (the spears) (while) doing your pig-hunting (lit: pig-spearing), that is your business, they are your spears.'

Knowledge Point: An interesting structure, and not much described in Papuan languages, is one where a same-subject medial clause is in the scope of the nominalization. In Mauwake this tends to happen when the medial verb shares an object with the following verb and there is no, or very little, intervening material between the verbs \REF{ex:5:x1885}, \REF{ex:5:x1845}.
Content 1: \gll Dabe wiawi \textbf{maa} \textbf{ik-ep} \textbf{en-owa} na-ep manin(a) koora iw-a-k. | \gls Dabe 3s/p.father food roast-SS.SEQ eat-NMZ say-SS.SEQ garden house go-PA-3s | \glt  `Dabe's father wanted to roast and eat food and went to the garden house.'
Content 2: \gll Toiyan iiriw maak-ep-pu-a-mik, \textbf{uuriw} \textbf{yia} \textbf{aaw-ep} \textbf{Madang} \textbf{ikiw-owa} nain. | \gls Toiyan already tell-SS.SEQ-CMPL-PA-1/3p morning 1p.ACC take-SS.SEQ Madang go-NMZ that1 | \glt  `We already told Toiyan about taking us in the morning and going to Madang.'

Knowledge Point: Medial clauses preceding nominalized clauses do not automatically fall within the scope of the nominalization. Just looking at the linguistic form it would be possible to analyse the following examples so that the medial clause is outside the nominalization. In that case the free translation of \REF{ex:5:x1227} would be `Having worked on the garden alone it is not acceptable to leave it there', and \REF{ex:5:x1239} `Hold the planting stick and keep practising the making of planting holes'. But culturally these alternative interpretations are not valid. Even starting to work on a big garden without previous negotiations and proper rituals is not acceptable, and the holding of the planting stick and making planting holes form a cultural `expectancy chain' and belong together conceptually.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Manina} \textbf{waisow} \textbf{mauw-ap} \textbf{neeke} \textbf{wafur-ap-pu-owa} nain weetak. | \gls garden 3s.ISOL work-SS.SEQ there.CF throw-SS.SEQ-CMPL-NMZ that1 no | \glt  `Working on the garden alone and leaving it there (=without proper rituals) is not (acceptable/customary).'
Content 2: \gll [\textbf{Weria} \textbf{op-ap} \textbf{wiinar-owa}] nain akim-am-ik-e. | \gls planting.stick hold-SS.SEQ make.planting.holes-NMZ that1 try-SS.SIM-be-IMP.2s | \glt  `Keep practising the making of planting holes with the planting stick.'

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:5:x1844} the medial clause has to be within the scope of the nominalization for the sentences to make sense. The speaker had seen a possum in a tree and would have liked to shoot it, but since he had not taken his bow and arrows with him, he did not climb up the tree either.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Nomokowa} \textbf{ir-ap} \textbf{mik-owa} nain yena amia me aaw-e-m. | \gls tree climb-SS.SEQ shoot-NMZ that 1s.GEN bow not take-PA-1s | \glt  `(For) climbing the tree and shooting (an animal), I hadn't taken my bow (and arrows).'

Knowledge Point: An intervening overt object may block a same-subject medial clause from being within the scope of a following nominalized verb \REF{ex:5:x1886}. A different-subject medial clause does not fall within the scope of a nominalized verb.
Content 1: \gll Irak-ep \textbf{luuwa} niir-owa piipu-a-mik. | \gls fight-SS.SEQ ball play-NMZ leave-PA-1/3p | \glt  `We fought and stopped (lit: left) playing football.'

Knowledge Point: The nominalized clause has several different functions. Like any other noun phrase, it may function as an argument \REF{ex:5:x1230} or in the periphery of a clause \REF{ex:5:x1241}, or in another noun phrase \REF{ex:5:x1229}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Epia} \textbf{wilin-owa}\textsubscript{O} uruf-ap bom yia wafur-om-i-kuan na-e-mik. | \gls firewood shine-NMZ see-SS.SEQ bomb 1p.ACC throw-BEN-Np-FU.3p say-PA-1/3p | \glt  `They\textsubscript{i}/we said that when they\textsubscript{j} see the light (lit: shining) of the fire they\textsubscript{j} will throw bombs at us.'
Content 2: \gll Wiena oram niir-emi \textbf{wiam} \textbf{kookal}\textbf{-}\textbf{owa=pa}\textsubscript{Advl} nan wiam aaw-i-mik. | \gls 3p.GEN just play-SS.SEQ 3p.REFL like-NMZ=LOC there 3p.REFL take-Np-PR.3s | \glt  `They just play together and (on the basis of) liking each other they marry each other.'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{garanga} \textbf{oko} \textbf{muuka} \textbf{wiar} \textbf{aaw-owa}\textsubscript{NP} sira\textsubscript{NP} | \gls family other son/child 3.DAT get-NMZ custom | \glt  `the adoption custom' (Lit: the custom of getting a child from another family')

Knowledge Point: Expressions of obligation (\sectref{sec:6.1.2}) use the nominalized form of the main verb. It is followed by the contrastive focus clitic, when it is either a non-verbal predicate \REF{ex:5:x1242}, \REF{ex:5:x1244} or the subject of the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ikua} `is' \REF{ex:5:x1243}.
Content 1: \gll Yo uurika owow maneka \textbf{ikiw-owa=ke}. | \gls 1s.UNM tomorrow village big go-NMZ=CF | \glt  `I have to go to town tomorrow.'
Content 2: \gll Inasina wia patir-a-mik nain \textbf{me} \textbf{wiar} \textbf{en-owa=ke}. | \gls bush.spirit 3p.ACC sacrifice-PA-1/3p that1 not 3.DAT eat-NMZ=CF | \glt  `One must not eat what has been sacrificed to the bush spirits.'
Content 3: \gll Wi iperowa ekima wia op-ap \textbf{baliwep} \textbf{ik-owa=ke} \textbf{ik-ua}. | \gls 3p.UNM middle-aged forehead 3p.ACC hold-SS.SEQ well be-NMZ=CF be-PA.3s | \glt  `One has to respect\footnote{The verbal expression for respecting someone is ekima opowa `holding someone's forehead'.} the middle-aged/elderly and behave well.'

Knowledge Point: Directional verbs (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.4.5}) may take a nominalized clause as the goal. In many of these cases it is hard to distinguish between goal and purpose, which can be expressed via nominalization as well \REF{ex:5:x1245}.
Content 1: \gll Yo \textbf{emeria} \textbf{aaw-owa} urup-e-m. | \gls 1s.UNM woman take-NMZ ascend-PA-1s | \glt  `I came up to take my wife.'

Knowledge Point: Nominalized clauses are used as complements of various complement-taking verbs \REF{ex:5:x1246}, \REF{ex:5:x1248} (\sectref{sec:8.3.2}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Miiw-aasa} \textbf{muf-owa} \textbf{ikiw-owa} na-em-ik-omkun o ar-e-k. | \gls land-canoe pull-NMZ go-NMZ say-SS.SIM-be-1s/p.DS 3s.UNM die-PA-3s | \glt  `As we were talking about going to get a vehicle, she died.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Maa} \textbf{uup-owa} paayar-ep ep-a-n. | \gls food cook-NMZ know-SS.SEQ come-PA-2s | \glt  `You know cooking and you came.'

Knowledge Point: A nominalized clause is sometimes used to express habituality. It indicates a more deliberate and permanent habit than that expressed by the continuous aspect, which is the default marking for the habitual \REF{ex:5:x1249}, \REF{ex:5:x1250} (\sectref{sec:3.8.5.1.1}).
Content 1: \gll Wi mua \textbf{naap} \textbf{me} \textbf{onowa} \textbf{nain=ko} ik-e-mik=i? | \gls 3p.UNM man thus not do-NMZ that1=NF be-PA-1/3p=QM | \glt  `Are there people who wouldn't keep doing like that?'
Content 2: \gll Mua papako \textbf{opor(a)} \textbf{makena} \textbf{me} \textbf{ookowa}, sira samora on-am-ika-i-mik. | \gls man other talk true not follow-NMZ custom bad do-SS-SIM-be-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt  `Some people (as a rule) do not follow the true talk (but) keep doing bad things.'

Knowledge Point: Mauwake verbs may take a causative suffix, which often indicates causation (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.3.1}). When the causation is less mechanical and requires the cooperation of the object of the causation, the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{suuw}- `push' is used together with a nominalized clause \REF{ex:5:x1252}:
Content 1: \gll Mua naareke \textbf{naap} \textbf{on-owa} nefa suuw-a-k? | \gls man who.CF thus do-NMZ 2s.ACC push-PA-3s | \glt  `Who made you do like that?'

Knowledge Point: Ability is expressed via a nominalized clause followed by the intensity adverb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{pepek} `enough, able' \REF{ex:5:x1251}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ariwa} \textbf{perek-owa} me pepek. | \gls arrow pull.out-NMZ not enough/able | \glt  `(He was) not able to pull out the arrow.'

Knowledge Point: One strategy for purposives is to use the nominalized form of the main verb followed by the same-subject sequential form \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naep} of the verb `say/think'. This strategy is used especially when the purpose is understood to be somewhat generic \REF{ex:5:x1253} or when the purpose clause is right-dislocated \REF{ex:5:x1255}. For purpose clauses, see \sectref{sec:8.3.2.1.4}.
Content 1: \gll Weniwa=pa \textbf{en-owa} \textbf{na-ep} uuw-i-mik. | \gls hunger.time=LOC eat-NMZ say-SS.SEQ plant-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt  `We/they work in order to eat during the time of hunger.'
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Mauwake has an idiosyncratic clausal structure for the expression `not yet'. The negated verb is nominalized, and it is followed by an appropriate form of the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}- `be' \REF{ex:5:x1254}. The presence of the negative temporal adverb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{eewuar} `not yet' indicates expectation that what hasn't happened yet will, or should, take place in not too distant future \REF{ex:5:x1256}.
Content 1: \gll Aakisa baliwep \textbf{me} \textbf{amis-ar-owa} \textbf{ik-e-mik}. | \gls now well not knowledge-INCH-NMZ be-PA-1/3p | \glt  `Now we do not yet know it well.'
Content 2: \gll Iwera popoka wafur-am-ika-iwkin or-op `bulak', \textbf{eewuar}, eka \textbf{me} \textbf{saan-ar-owa} \textbf{ik-ua}. | \gls coconut unripe throw-SS.SIM-be-2/3p.DS descend-SS.SEQ plop not.yet water not dry-INCH-NMZ be-PA.3s | \glt  `They\textsubscript{i} kept throwing unripe coconuts\textsubscript{j} and when they\textsubscript{j} dropped they\textsubscript{j} said `plop' (so they\textsubscript{i} knew:) not yet, the water had not dried yet.'

Knowledge Point: Unlike many other languages, in Mauwake a nominalized clause does not function as a complement of an adjective. Rather, the nominalized clause functions as the subject and it takes the adjective as a non-verbal predicate \REF{ex:5:x1258}, \REF{ex:5:x1259}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Maa} \textbf{wiar} \textbf{ikum} \textbf{aaw-owa} eliwa=ki? | \gls thing 3.DAT illicitly take-NMZ good=CF.QM | \glt  `Is it good to steal?'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Galasim-owa}{\upshape\footnotemark} lawisiw yoowa. | \gls spear.fish-NMZ rather hot/hard | \glt  `Spearing fish is rather hard.' Or: `It is rather hard to spear fish.'

Knowledge Point: The distribution of finite clauses nominalized only with a demonstrative is more restricted than that of clauses with a nominalized verb. They function as complement clauses \REF{ex:5:x1260} (\sectref{sec:8.3.2}), relative clauses \REF{ex:5:x1261} (\sectref{sec:8.3.1}), or temporal clauses \REF{ex:5:x1940} (\sectref{sec:8.3.3.1}), but not in the many other specific functions where the other type can occur. Forming complement clauses and relative clauses by adding a demonstrative pronoun after a finite verb is a common strategy in Papuan languages (\citealt{Reesink1983b}; \citeyear[228]{Reesink1987}; \citealt[77]{Farr1999}; \citealt[192]{Whitehead2004}).
